page.title: 05THE CAUSEY AND CAUSEY ARCH
page.content: {THE CAUSEY}is a beautiful wooded area in County Durham,2km N.E.of Tanfield and 4km N of Stanley.It is a popular picnic area owned by the National Trust.It derives its name from an elevated Roman road. {THE CAUSEY ARCH}was built of stone in 1725/6 at the cost of Â£12,000,to carry coalwaggons across the ravine,from the Tanfield coalmines to the River Tyne. Designed and built by Ralph Mason,at the request of the local mineowners known as the "GRAND ALLIES",the bridge has a span of 32m and is 34m high. Fearing the bridge might collapse Mason committed suicide by jumping from the completed Arch. This oldest surviving railway viaduct in the world has recently been restored by Durham County Council. A wooden waggon and track have been added as it would have been in 1760.
